By DENNIS ESTIS
Student Council representatives
Bud Bozarth and Ken Borow walked out of last Monday night's
meeting in order to prevent the
S.C. from taking a specific stand
on the question of U.S. involvement in Viet Nam.
The legislative manoeuvre,
which was likened to the Southern
filibustering tactics by some Council members, suspended the business of that body because a quorum no longer existed.
"Deviousness"
Many of the S.C. members were
outraged at the "deviousness" of
this act. Kenneth Bond, junior
class representative, summarized
the majority's feelings by calling
the Bozarth-Borow walkout, "a
flagrantly irresponsible action."

Poll Reveals
Draft Sentiment
were permanently deferred, and
the same percentage said that they
did not know what they would
do. Combining the number who
would seek to avoid induction by
either legal or extra-legal means
with the number of those who
would serve against their will, 61
or 62.9%,indicated that they were
reluctant to serve in the military.
The figures for the total response (377) showed that 6.1%
(23) would probably join or had
joined the military; 25.5% •(96)
would sillingly serve if drafted;
19.1% (72), including those who
would do so after exhausting legal
attempts to avoid the military,

Preceding the incident, Jack
Kirk, Senior Class President, had
introduced a motion which would
give the Student Council the right
to take their own stand on the issue of Viet Nam. The motion was
approved by a 10-5 vote, with
Borow, Bozarth, Bruce Resnick,
and Dean Rudoy among the five
negative votes.
Borow, in an attempt to delay
the Council's action, introduced a
motion to have the S.C. wait on its
decision until after the nationwide
college- presidential preference primary, "Choice 68, is held next
month. Kilt argued that the Student Council did not have to act
like a Gallup Poll; and its members
had every right, as campus leaders,
to voice their own composite
opinions on such issues. Borow's
motion was defeated 10-5.
Bill Betcher, President of the
Freshman Class, moved that S.C.
President Bruce Ledig appoint a
committee to formulate a draft
resolution which the Council could
vote on at next week's meeting.
After a great deal of discussion,
the roll call was begun, and at this
time,both Borow and Bozarth left
the meeting.

Bozarth, Vice-President of the
Council, stated that his action was
based on two points which he considered "legitimate and not a lark"
First, Bozarth stated that the
"Student Council was not competent to represent the opinions of
the Hopkins undergraduate student body on such matters;" and
second, that "the composition of
the Council at the meeting was not
representative of the total Council."

Drake Estis New Dooks

New Architecture Might
Save City Says Moynihan

BRUCE DRAKE, unidentified tart, and Dennis Estis, drink to the
new look News-Letter slated to start under their editorship next
week.
Bruce Drake and Dennis Estis
were selected Editors-in-Chief in
the 73rd Annual News-Letter elections last Tuesday night. They succeed Peter Koper and Roger Toll
in that position.
Drake,a 19 year old sophomore
from East Rockaway, New York,
is an English major.
Estis is a 20 year old junior
from Newark, New Jersey. His
major is political science.
David Cooper and James Franke
were chosen to serve a second year
as Business Managers.
Peter Harnik will leave his post
as Copy Editor and move into the
the newly created Editorial Chairman spot. Harnik will be a combination managing editor and righthand man to the new editors-inchief.
Neil Grauer and Elia Katz will
fill the positions of Contributing

Editors. The Associate Editors
posts will be taken over by former
Sports Editor Jim Sloan and Stephen Shriver.
Drake's former post as News
Editor is being filled by Richard
Cramer and 'Sloan's position as
Sports Editor will be filled by Richard Hollander. The Features Edtor post which has been vacant all
year will be filled by Seth Feldman.
Taking over Harnik's post as
Copy Editor will be Robert Sloan.
Tom Hoffman will try to continue
to produce the clear pictures which
have been indicative of the paper
in his post as Photography Editor.
This week's issue of the NewsLetter will be the last for Dooks
Koper and Toll. The new staff will
take over for next week's issue.
"We have two tiny pairs of
shoes to fill," chimed the Dynamic
Duo, in unison.

I Campus Notes I
FILM FEST
The second annual Maryland
Film Festival will be held concurrently at Hopkins, Goucher
and the Maryland Institute of
Art from March 7 through the
10th.
At Goucher the film fest will
be held March 7, 8 and 9 at 8:30
p.m. in the Louise Kelley Lecture
Hall. At the Maryland Institute
the film's' will be shown in the
Mount Royal Station Auditorium
on March 8.9 and 10 at 8:30 p.m.
At Johns Hopkins, the festival will
be held in Shaffer Hall Auditorium. One program will be shown
on March 9 at 8:30 p.m. The
remaining two programs will be
shown on March 10, one at 2:30
p.m. and the other at 8:30 p.m.
COURSE GUIDE
All professors and graduate students who have not received their

questionnaires concerning the
next edition of the Course Guide
are requested to drop a note to
Box 816.
LIVELY TO SPEAK
Walter Lively, Executive Director of the Baltimore Urban Coalition and Director of U-JOIN, and
Dr. James Coleman of the Department of Social Relations, will
speak in the Great Hall of Levering
Monday, March 11, at 7:30 p.m.
They will discuss the "Theories
and Practices of Social Change
with Special Emphasis on the
Problems and Solutions in and for
Baltimore." The forum is sponsored by SDS:
HANDBOOK STAFF
Anyone who is interested in
working on the SA Handbook for
next fall should leave his name and
address at the SA office in Levering or in Box 2093 in the dormitory mail room. Work will begin in
two weeks.

Monk to Explain
SE Asia Crises
On Sunday, March 10, the Levering Hall Student Association,
the Johns Hopkins YMCA, will
sponsor two appearances by the
South Vietnamese Buddhist Monk,
Thich Nhat Hanh, author of Vietnam: Lotusin a Sea of Fire.
Nhat Hank will speak first at
an Ecumenical Service in Shriver
Hall at 11 A.M. The title of his
talk is "Vietnam: Lotus in a Sea of
Fire." He will speak again at 3 p.m.
in Levering, Great Hall. The lecture, Titled "What the Vietnamese
Really Want", will be followed by
a question and answer period.

THICH NHAT HANH
Thick Nhat Hank was professor
of Religion at Van Hanh University in Saigon, and Editor of the
Buddhist periodical, Thien My.
More important, he was the founder/director of the Buddhist School
of Youth for Social Service.
The school has begun to meet
many pressing needs of the country - rural health and sanitation,
the improvement of agricultrual
techniques, the eradication of illiteracy and educational deficiencies.
Asked by Cornell
In 1966, Thick Nhat Hanh was
asked by Cornell University to deliver a series of lectures on Vietnamese Buddhism.
Vietnam: Lotus of the Sea of

languages, and is in its third printing in the United States.

America since May, 1966. He can

Babee, The Last Time
"It may sound funny," replied the soldier to the newspaperman
last week, "But I miss the T.V. commercials back home the most."
An amazing statement. From the midst of absurdity comes the
ontological truth of mid-century. It used to be that America was portrayed by steeples in New England and fields in the Midwest. If you
would like to see America today, you can watch the sinus cavities
drain as Dristar does its work.
A description of the human condition. We have dwelt among the
castles in the sand, we have lived with the artificialities of economics,
now we resign our reality to the sixty-second television commercial.
Are we so frail? We must despair. For castles made of sand slip
into the sea, eventually. What lies behind the Pepsodent commercial?
One is afraid to think that there is only darkness after the projector
has been turned off.
And so here we are, you and I. Our life constructed of gay colors,
linoleum floors, and party dresses. Perhaps we should look for a way
of thinking. Perhaps we should rearrange our priorities. Perhaps we
should stop asking small questions and ask only one very big
Question.
Maybe we could all get together and have a Sunday picnic. Everyone in the world would be invited and balloons would be sold. On
the balloons we shall have printed "Things Go Better With CocaCola."

I, Buster, have called you here
to tell you something not as old as
other things you have been told

that there seem to be in this society two desires motivating two

facts pertinent to one's daily existence; and the other, an unhealthy

But what are we to think about the soldier who with the final
bloody twitch of muscles gasps,"Drano." We should think of him as
we think of ourselves, for it is our nightmare as well as his.
Children of the forthcoming doom, we have no answer for you.
You don't even have an answer. It would be considered advantageous
to formulate some kind of speech to deliver in front of your burning
house this summer. Address the black masses with something besides
quotations from CBS, however, because they don't speak your
language.
We have heard reports that pc.,bole still make love and go to the
food from time to time, albathroom occassionally. They also
though it is getting more expensive. These are all good signs. It means
that these are values we are given simply because we live in our
bodies. Other values do not come easily.
And it is this questio of values, priorities, that we must face. To
continue in the manner history is accustomed to, priorities have to be
rewritten and pondered. We have to decide that nirvana is nowhere,
and that heaven is a drag.
What we must do, eventually, is metamorphosize into a race of
Plastic Men. Able to fill any container we find ourselves in. Television
commercials, it must be remembered, are made of celluloid. T -igs
never change, things remain the same.
Things move fast these days, and acquiescence will keep us alive
but hardly living. We wish you a quiet death in black and white.

A Journalistic Digression
Over the past year,as usual, the purpose and content of the NewsLetter have met heated criticism. The purpose of this paper has always been clear to us. We want to arouse controversy, we want to
criticize- the University in areas we feel need reform - - not only to
make the News-Letter a good paper, but to make the University a
better place to spend our four years. Though, as the only weekly
publication, we have an obligation to comprehensively report on campus news, we have tried to broaden our content with relevant information and comment on the political, social and artistic scenes. The
Hopkins student body is introverted enough; perhaps the News-Letter is the medium to change this attitude.
This has been our policy for the last year. It is a policy'which we
hope the new editors will continue.

GREENWOOD GAS
To the Editors:
Getting down to Greenwood's
Garage to pick up your car after
it's been towed away from a Badly
Chosen parking spot is a real pain
in the ass (or so I've been told). It
has become a famous pain in the
ass since a participant in the recent
conference designed to improve
Hopkins' relations with the community had his car towed away.
Since a fine goes with the violation
anyway, now that Hopkins has
purchased a garage near the campus, why not have cars towed
there instead?
Rich Conviser
Social Relations
NEIN TO THE VECTOR
To the Editors:
In response to your article on
the "demise" of the Vector, I
would like to say first that neither
the SAC nor Mr. Bilgrave's office
was approached by any of your reporters concerning the issue in an
effort to seek out the facts.
The Vector is not put to rest by
any means nor is it meant to be a
money-making business. For that
matter, we do not consider the
News-Letter to be a money-making
business either. Our only stipulation monetarily is that an organization should not incur a debt at the
end of the academic year.
In May of each year the president of the Student Council, the
Chairman of the SAC, and Mr.
Bilgrave meet to review the past
operations of each organization
and to. decide on the budgets for
the forthcoming year. Naturally
every organization would like some
increase in its funds and when
sound reasons and past performances are presented increases are very
possible. Certainly the News-Letter can attest to this.
Now, the question at hand is
the Vector. Without using figures
the Vector incurred a substantial
debt at the end of last year due
mainly to the publication of its
May issue. Charles Polnitsky, editor-in-chief of the Vector, at that
time said that he and his staff had
miscalculated advertising revenues
and printing costs but that a subscription campaign was already in
the planning stages for this year.
By manipulating funds and seeking emergency university funds we
were able to match a yearly budget
for this year even after deducting
the deficit.
We acknowledge the unfortunate results of the subscription
campaign. We acknowledge the effort and time spent by the Vector
staff. We acknowledge the Vector's
attempt at revitalization. But, we
cannot acknowledge irresponsibility. In putting out a publication
such as the Vector or the NewsLetter there is a two-fold and equal
task. One is to achieve its artistic
purpose and the other is to maintain itself financially.
From speaking with Mr. Polnitsky it appears that neither he nor
his staff can meet this responsibility. First, he told us that neither
he nor his editorial staff would
take any responsibility for the debt
incurred last spring. Secondly, he
said that they would not take the
responsibility for failing to publish
the last two issues this year as they
are already in debt from the first
two issues. And lastly, if we could
not meet their financial demands
neither he nor his staff would take
the responsibility for publishing a
Vector next year.
Alternate solutions were offered to Mr. Polnitsky by Mr. Bilgrave and myself and it was made
clear that the Vector would receive a budget of $800 — $1,000
for next year.
Jed P. Luchow
Chairman, SAC

Correspondence
SWEET ELLA
To the Editors:
I have just finished reading
"Yes,Virginia, There Are Students
Who Don't Protest" by Ella Katz.
Perhaps she is right, maybe she is
wrong. However, I can only conclude that the writer has a sick,
warped mind. In talking about a
better world in which to live shei
says - - "Nobody said they would
stop the war or build highways or
pass gun legislation or effect free
telephone service or kill the Jews
or force little girls to give them
pleasure. At least the latter part of
the sentence shows a macabre
sense of humor at the worst a diseased mind. There was a Hitler
who thought this way once
6,000,000 Jews paid the price.
With such statements can any of us
truly believe that the writer, or
even the editors, are truly concerned about the oppressed and underprivileged of this world.Your own
words give the lie back to you.
Perhaps there is yet one more protest due at Johns Hopkins. Let all
fair-minded students organize and
protest the printing of such diabolical slander in the News-Letter.
I further hope that the Editors
of News-Letter have the decency
to publicly apologize for the sickening statement which they printed.
You claim to be for decency.
Prove it.
Sick at heart,
Simon Cohen
TAYLOR FARCE
To the Editors:
In September, my parents were
suckered into taking out health insurance for my wife and myself
under that phony plan sponsored
by Hopkins. I remember an editorial of yours that criticized the
boys in Whitehead Hall for advertising their plan to our parents in a
very misleading fashion.
In early October, my wife sustained a minor injury in the kitchen. We had the injury treated at
a local hospital. I payed the bill
myself, notified the company, filled out a detailed report of the accident,and sent the report and my
receipt on to the company.
That was in November. 1 have
received no answer from the company. Great way to run an insurance company, write policies and
ignore claims. I wonder what size.
of a kickback the boys at Whitehead have received.
Bert Miller
POOR POLL
To the Editors:
The Student Council Poll in
last weeks News-Letter and the
News-Letter Draft Poll being distributed this week are all very nice
but not really very useful, or at
least the Student Council Poll
wasn't.
Last week SC Poll statistics said
that 90% of the students responding to the poll were unhappy with
Johnson's policy in Vietnam, 51%
approve of Napalm, etc., but nowhere does it say how many people don't give a damn and didn't
bother to answer. If 10% of the
students are doves and 5% are
hawks, and only these 15% answered the poll, you can say that
two thirds of the students are
doves but it isn't really honest to
to do so, because only a few people answered and these few cannot
be taken as a representative sample.
Based on the above it is also
possible to say only 10% of the
students consider themselves doves
or only 5% consider themselves
hawks.. As presented, the results
are essentially meaningless and useless for anything except providing
front;page pyroof..o.r .evidence. to

support somebody's point of view
and they can be distorted to prove
just about anything.
HOW MANY STUDENTS ANSWERED THE POLL AND HOW
MANY DIDN'T?!?
I would very much like to see
the results of the Student Council
Poll presented again only with
HONEST statistics, including how
many students did and didn't
respond. I would also like to see
the News-Letter Draft Poll results
presented in the same way.
Whatever they are, I'd like to
see the FACTS presented in the
News-Letter, not somebody's pet
opinion. I don't think I have been
seeing them.
James Weston
Class of'68

In the second of the Milton S.

Dr. Charles Abrams. Director of

situation in America.
Dr. Abrams speech concentrated on the racial and housing
problems faced by the cities. His
main points focused on the government's inability to deal with
these problems.
Dr. Abrams spoke of the division between blacks and whites
which he believes is growing. He
agreed with the President's Commission on Civil Disorders and
Spoke of their report as a "great
document.- Like the Commission,
he predicted more riots this summer, and laid the blame on the
government's apathy.

federal housing policy and how it
fails to meet the problem. He
said that most cities have a large
amount of relatively cheap housing
and that the bill does not aid the
Poor in becoming home-owners
because it does not provide mortgage funds. Dr. Abrams believes
that Ownership is a great antidote
against destructive rioting.
In conclusion, he called for a
complete re-orientation in America's thinking about urban affairs.

The Johns Hopkins Viet Nam
Committee, which has declined recently due to a lack of interest on
the campus, is now making an attempt to revive itself to serve as a
vehicle of dissent for those who
oppose the war.
The Viet Nam Committee has
distributed almost 4,000 questionaires in order to determine the
mood of the students and faculty
members on campus. According to
a committee officer, response to
the survey indicates that opinion
at Hopkins runs more than threeto-one against the war.
27 Members
The group felt that the need
for reorganization, since, despite
the anti-war sentiment at Hopkins, membership in the committee
remains small. Since the October
Peace March, membership has declined until less than thirty people
remain actively participating. Many
students have left the Viet Nam
Committee in favor of the Students for McCarthy organization.
The organization has been restructured with three, or perhaps
four, subcommittees under a coordinating committee. First, there is
the committee for Hopkins Affairs,
designed to provide interest and
action on campus through a series
of debates and lectures by faculty
members.
Steady Stream
Second is the Press Committee,
Whose members would be informed on the policies of major news
Publications in regard to the war.
This committee is also responsible
for issuing a steady stream of letto the publications, condemn-

ing Viet Nam policies.
Third is the Literature Committee, responsible for the maintainance of the literature table in Levering Hall. Finally, a committee
to communicate with anti-war organizations on other campuses
might be formed. Its purpose
would be to orangize a united

front of thousands protesting the
war instead of the many small
groups which now exist.

Unsuccessful
The Committee has been less
than wholly successful in its revitalization program. Membership
and participation has not increased
appreciably. Those whom the corn-

mittee asks to conduct lectures or
debates feel that enough is already
being done.
The leadership of the committee would like to merge their organization with another group at
Hopkins. This move, they feel
would lend a broader base to the
anti-war movement on campus. At

this point, the members are urged
to join Students for McCarthy,
RESIST, or both. The Viet Nam
Committee believes that the only
way to achieve any of its goals is
through a large and unified organization, comprised of all of the
anti-war factions.

By KENNETH BOND
It is ironic that a little over
four months ago there were five
legitimate contenders for the Republican presidential nomination.
Now there is only one: Richard
M. Nixon, or two if you're counting Harold Stassen. When Big
George pulled out last week he was
only stating the obvious. He came
in like a winner and went out
gracefully. But in between Romney died from a severe case of
foot-in-mouth disease. His "great
White father" image smacked of
hypocrisy; his rising from the rear
strategy was politically perverse.
So now George Romney is a tool
of the historian's imagination.
Farewell, George.
To those of us, however, who
dread giving the GOP nod to Nixon
as a sop for saving the party banner all these many years, Romney
could have been a little more courageous to withdraw in favor of
another contender, i.e. Nelson
Rockefeller, his long-time supportter. Perhaps it was just bad timing,

Anti - Climactical Venom Titillates Town
By JAMES BENNETT
You saw the ad. Venom! Debauchery on the beach and in the
bedroom! Banned in Denmark!
No admittance under 18! With the
inevitable result that we all hotfooted it down to the 7th East,
flashed our student cards, scrambled into our seats, and foreheads
beaded with perspiration sat waiting for the curtain to rise with delicious visions of Scandanavian
perversions dancing through our
heads.
All of which made for an exasperating evening. For every time
the plot was threatening to thicken
(congeal is perhaps closer) the action would be blocked out by an
enormous X which, in order to fill
in the gaps in the story line, automatically forced one to employ his
imagination (Which is sorely deficient to begin with. Why else
would I have paid the fare?).
If one can conceive of the intellectual fodder resulting from
Francoise Sagan rewriting Bonjour
Tristesse while in her late forties
then one has a somewhat clearer

picture of what Venom had to offer the viewer. For it's all about
this positively beastly young man
named Per who sets about corrupting the morals of sweet little Suzanne, the innocent (but built)
daughter of a wealthy businessman
who is himself experiencing marital woes.
Scintillating in her
one piece bathing suit our heroine
is seductively stretched out on the
family's private water front soaking up the sun and trying to cram
for University finals when she
meets Evil Incarnate in the guise
of Per. Now Per, if you're still
with me, seeing what he likes best
ignores the posted Do Not Enter
signs, storms up the beach, snows
poor Suzanne before she can so
much as turn another page in her
Biology text, and proceeds, all in
one shot, to convince her to star
in a film he is currently piecing together on the hypocrisy of traditional morals. With a little help
from his friends Per eventually
manages to come up with some
downright fascinating home movies. With absolutely nothing going

to the cutting room floor Suzanne's mother is given a sneak preview and nearly gags at her daughter's indelicate part. Needless to
say daddy is telephoned at the office straight away.
Well after that the tension just
hits a feverish'pitch. And there we
sat, horny little prigs that we are,
while director Knud Leif Thornsen (pronounced nude leaf) rambled on about the nasty and less
than discrete morals practised by
mom and dad and Suzanne and
Per. And we lapped it up.
Sad to think that Pietro Germi's
tender tale of real life and real
morals should be prematurely ushered out by the management to
make room for something as dismal as this. For those faster than a
speeding bullet who , like myself,
managed to catch The Climax before its almost simultaneous arrival
and departure were treated to a
poignantly filmed story of a wildly
energetic Italian who happens to
have three wives stashed around
the countryside., The strain of an
impossible family life has begun to

cleanse his conscience by confessing all to a priest. But his domestic problems prove just as complicated to his kindly confessor who
is unable to suggest a workable
solution. "What can I do?" the
penitent Don Juan asks helplessly.
"Should I divorce them?" The
good father at this point is at his
wits end as to how he should best
counsel this sorrowful sinner.
Bleary-eyed after much soul
searching he blurts out hopelessly,
"Yes, yes, divorce. That's it." But
it was only an unguarded emotional outburst and he quickly recants.
"My, God," he cries. "Divorce!
What am I saying!"
The dialogue of Climax reveals
the real world, and the sheltered
world of the Church whose decrees periodically emanate from
behind the cloistered stone walls
of the Vatican. Director Germi
raises the question as to whether
the Catholic Hierarchy can, even in
its infinite wisdom, truly establish
feasible guidelines for moral conduct in an impossible world.

the presence of upcomers from a
fairly capable 9-5 freshman group
next year's cage prospects would
• superficially appear reasonably
good. However, a recurrent Hopkins cage malady - deterioration of
player performance with experience — renders any such prognosis
extremely doubtful, and is perhaps
Symptomatic of more fundamental
problems in the basketball program
here.
That, despite Ciccarone's avowals of relative satisfaction, things
are not, and have not been, quite
right on the Hopkins cage scene, is
by now no more than a truism.
Signs of some underlying malady
— for example, the obvious disparity between individual abilities
and team performances; the gap
between the records of recent
freshman teams (28-14 overall)
and the varsity squads derived
from them (25-28); the sharp
game-to-game form vacillations;
the failure of experienced performers (this year, '66-67 lettermen
Dave Thomas and Will Lane) to
turn out; and (wherever the blame
lies) the unseemly nature of CaIli's
benching and departure — are not
insubstantial, and the individual
declines mentioned above are quite
amenable to empirical verification.
The best examples of this "deterioration
with experience",
Which by its widespread occurence
absolves from much personal
blame those involved, are seniors
Calli, Sullivan, and Carlton. The
former averaged 17.5 points per
game his sophomore year, fell to
15.8 in '66-67, and was 9.9 this
time around; his corresponding
field goal percentages were 40%,
33%, and 34%. Sullivan (12.5, 8.6,
5.3 and 42%, 32%, 39%) and Carlton (9.9, 7.7, and 5.2 and 10.5,
8.7, and 6.3 rebounds per game)
Show roughly similar pattersn.
Decreased playing time caused
by influxes of new talent and
greater squad depth and balance
are likely partial explanation for
these declines, but to assign to
such causes full responsibility
therefore is not justified. The

BILL SWARTZ — Senior co-captain battles Hal White of Towson
State. Swartz went on to defeat White 8-2, in the semi-final round of
the Mason Dixon tournament.
SWIMMING CHAMPIONSHIPS
Last weekend with only six swimmers and one diver the Jays' varsity squad ended its season and finished fifth in the Middle Atlantic
Conference swimming and diving championships.
The Jays garnered two gold medals; both belonging to Howard
Chernick, who swept the butterfly events. Rick Wilson, the defending one meter broad champ, lost his first conference meet competition, finishing second behind Allen of Elizabethtown. Junior Vaughn
Weikel picked up two silver medals in the backstroke and 200 yd
individual medley.

Bill Charyk, the only Hopkins
student to hold a first degree black
belt in karate, yesterday leant
across his opponents, splintered
simultaneously five boards, and
shattered several cinder blocks in
a public demonstration at the
Newton H. White Athletic Center.
The purpose of the exhibition
was to give to students an idea of
what karate training can do. He also hopes to attract students to his
evening classes which are to begin
next Tuesday.
In addition to Charyk's tour de
force, several of his already ranked
students assisted in the hour program including basic holds and defences, spinning kicks, plus several
bouts of "free sparing",(a technically precise free-for-all).
Bill Charyk likewise demonstrated possible defences against knife
attacks. He also fought off six
"attackers" during the evening.
Charyk teaches Tae Kwan Do,
the style of karate which is taught
to American Troops in Vietnam.

It is also the most preferred style
of the V.C. Tae K wan Do, one of
twenty karate styles, was introduced through Korea.
There are five stages of expertise leading finally to the black belt
status. The initial or beginning
stage is the gold belt, followed by
the green, the blue, the brown and
the black belt.
At present, Charyk has five officially ranked students: four
freshmen holding the gold belt
and one blue belt. Charyk stated
that, in order to pass the first degree, student must work for somewhere between five to seven
months. Charyk has studied karate
for five years.
Jhoan Rhee, considered to be
the best instructor of karate in the
United States, has taught Charyk
during the last several years. Out
of nine possible degrees, Rhee is a
seventh degree black belt
The course which Charyk is
giving will hold its first meeting on
Tuesday, March 12, at 7:30.

Hopkins Grapplers
Take Poor Fifth

JAY'S NEST

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Smashed 92-53 by eventual
winner Muhlenberg in the M.A.C.
tournament's opening round, the
varsity basketball team concluded
another so-so campaign — Hopkins'
twenty-second consecutive nonwinning cage season — with a 9-10
overall mark.
In last Friday's tourney action,
Muhlenberg, host of the Southern
Division Middle Atlantic Conference affair, jumped off to an 18-8
edge over the first-seeded Jays by
9:41 of the first half; and held
leads of from eight to fourteen
points until midway through the
second. Ahead 57-44 with 9:00
left, the Mules then turned on the
heat over the game's remainder,
scoring sixteen straight points in
the ensuing three minutes while
blitzing the bewildered Homewood
squad 35-9 down the stretch.
Although the affair hardly rated
as one of Hopkins' better hoop
performances (the team shot 30%
from the field,and made but seven
of sixteen free throws), the size of
the loss was more a function of
Muhlenberg capabilities than Jay
inadequacies.The Allentown,(Pa.)
squad, whose fourth-place M.A.C.
finish belied its tournament showing and resulted mainly from its
own inconsistency, was probably

By DENNIS ESTIS
Student Council representatives
Bud Bozarth and Ken Borow walked out of last Monday night's
meeting in order to prevent the
S.C. from taking a specific stand
on the question of U.S. involvement in Viet Nam.
The legislative manoeuvre,
which was likened to the Southern
filibustering tactics by some Council members, suspended the business of that body because a quorum no longer existed.
"Deviousness"
Many of the S.C. members were
outraged at the "deviousness" of
this act. Kenneth Bond, junior
class representative, summarized
the majority's feelings by calling
the Bozarth-Borow walkout, "a
flagrantly irresponsible action."

Poll Reveals
Draft Sentiment
were permanently deferred, and
the same percentage said that they
did not know what they would
do. Combining the number who
would seek to avoid induction by
either legal or extra-legal means
with the number of those who
would serve against their will, 61
or 62.9%,indicated that they were
reluctant to serve in the military.
The figures for the total response (377) showed that 6.1%
(23) would probably join or had
joined the military; 25.5% •(96)
would sillingly serve if drafted;
19.1% (72), including those who
would do so after exhausting legal
attempts to avoid the military,

Preceding the incident, Jack
Kirk, Senior Class President, had
introduced a motion which would
give the Student Council the right
to take their own stand on the issue of Viet Nam. The motion was
approved by a 10-5 vote, with
Borow, Bozarth, Bruce Resnick,
and Dean Rudoy among the five
negative votes.
Borow, in an attempt to delay
the Council's action, introduced a
motion to have the S.C. wait on its
decision until after the nationwide
college- presidential preference primary, "Choice 68, is held next
month. Kilt argued that the Student Council did not have to act
like a Gallup Poll; and its members
had every right, as campus leaders,
to voice their own composite
opinions on such issues. Borow's
motion was defeated 10-5.
Bill Betcher, President of the
Freshman Class, moved that S.C.
President Bruce Ledig appoint a
committee to formulate a draft
resolution which the Council could
vote on at next week's meeting.
After a great deal of discussion,
the roll call was begun, and at this
time,both Borow and Bozarth left
the meeting.

Bozarth, Vice-President of the
Council, stated that his action was
based on two points which he considered "legitimate and not a lark"
First, Bozarth stated that the
"Student Council was not competent to represent the opinions of
the Hopkins undergraduate student body on such matters;" and
second, that "the composition of
the Council at the meeting was not
representative of the total Council."

Drake Estis New Dooks

New Architecture Might
Save City Says Moynihan

BRUCE DRAKE, unidentified tart, and Dennis Estis, drink to the
new look News-Letter slated to start under their editorship next
week.
Bruce Drake and Dennis Estis
were selected Editors-in-Chief in
the 73rd Annual News-Letter elections last Tuesday night. They succeed Peter Koper and Roger Toll
in that position.
Drake,a 19 year old sophomore
from East Rockaway, New York,
is an English major.
Estis is a 20 year old junior
from Newark, New Jersey. His
major is political science.
David Cooper and James Franke
were chosen to serve a second year
as Business Managers.
Peter Harnik will leave his post
as Copy Editor and move into the
the newly created Editorial Chairman spot. Harnik will be a combination managing editor and righthand man to the new editors-inchief.
Neil Grauer and Elia Katz will
fill the positions of Contributing

Editors. The Associate Editors
posts will be taken over by former
Sports Editor Jim Sloan and Stephen Shriver.
Drake's former post as News
Editor is being filled by Richard
Cramer and 'Sloan's position as
Sports Editor will be filled by Richard Hollander. The Features Edtor post which has been vacant all
year will be filled by Seth Feldman.
Taking over Harnik's post as
Copy Editor will be Robert Sloan.
Tom Hoffman will try to continue
to produce the clear pictures which
have been indicative of the paper
in his post as Photography Editor.
This week's issue of the NewsLetter will be the last for Dooks
Koper and Toll. The new staff will
take over for next week's issue.
"We have two tiny pairs of
shoes to fill," chimed the Dynamic
Duo, in unison.

Babee, The Last Time
"It may sound funny," replied the soldier to the newspaperman
last week, "But I miss the T.V. commercials back home the most."
An amazing statement. From the midst of absurdity comes the
ontological truth of mid-century. It used to be that America was portrayed by steeples in New England and fields in the Midwest. If you
would like to see America today, you can watch the sinus cavities
drain as Dristar does its work.
A description of the human condition. We have dwelt among the
castles in the sand, we have lived with the artificialities of economics,
now we resign our reality to the sixty-second television commercial.
Are we so frail? We must despair. For castles made of sand slip
into the sea, eventually. What lies behind the Pepsodent commercial?
One is afraid to think that there is only darkness after the projector
has been turned off.
And so here we are, you and I. Our life constructed of gay colors,
linoleum floors, and party dresses. Perhaps we should look for a way
of thinking. Perhaps we should rearrange our priorities. Perhaps we
should stop asking small questions and ask only one very big
Question.
Maybe we could all get together and have a Sunday picnic. Everyone in the world would be invited and balloons would be sold. On
the balloons we shall have printed "Things Go Better With CocaCola."

A Journalistic Digression
Over the past year,as usual, the purpose and content of the NewsLetter have met heated criticism. The purpose of this paper has always been clear to us. We want to arouse controversy, we want to
criticize- the University in areas we feel need reform - - not only to
make the News-Letter a good paper, but to make the University a
better place to spend our four years. Though, as the only weekly
publication, we have an obligation to comprehensively report on campus news, we have tried to broaden our content with relevant information and comment on the political, social and artistic scenes. The
Hopkins student body is introverted enough; perhaps the News-Letter is the medium to change this attitude.
This has been our policy for the last year. It is a policy'which we

To the Editors:
Getting down to Greenwood's
Garage to pick up your car after
it's been towed away from a Badly
Chosen parking spot is a real pain
in the ass (or so I've been told). It
has become a famous pain in the
ass since a participant in the recent
conference designed to improve
Hopkins' relations with the community had his car towed away.
Since a fine goes with the violation
anyway, now that Hopkins has
purchased a garage near the campus, why not have cars towed
there instead?
Rich Conviser
Social Relations
NEIN TO THE VECTOR
To the Editors:
In response to your article on
the "demise" of the Vector, I
would like to say first that neither
the SAC nor Mr. Bilgrave's office
was approached by any of your reporters concerning the issue in an
effort to seek out the facts.
The Vector is not put to rest by
any means nor is it meant to be a
money-making business. For that
matter, we do not consider the
News-Letter to be a money-making
business either. Our only stipulation monetarily is that an organization should not incur a debt at the
end of the academic year.
In May of each year the president of the Student Council, the
Chairman of the SAC, and Mr.
Bilgrave meet to review the past
operations of each organization
and to. decide on the budgets for
the forthcoming year. Naturally
every organization would like some
increase in its funds and when
sound reasons and past performances are presented increases are very
possible. Certainly the News-Letter can attest to this.
Now, the question at hand is
the Vector. Without using figures
the Vector incurred a substantial
debt at the end of last year due
mainly to the publication of its
May issue. Charles Polnitsky, editor-in-chief of the Vector, at that
time said that he and his staff had
miscalculated advertising revenues
and printing costs but that a subscription campaign was already in
the planning stages for this year.
By manipulating funds and seeking emergency university funds we
were able to match a yearly budget
for this year even after deducting
the deficit.
We acknowledge the unfortunate results of the subscription
campaign. We acknowledge the effort and time spent by the Vector
staff. We acknowledge the Vector's
attempt at revitalization. But, we
cannot acknowledge irresponsibility. In putting out a publication
such as the Vector or the NewsLetter there is a two-fold and equal
task. One is to achieve its artistic
purpose and the other is to maintain itself financially.
From speaking with Mr. Polnitsky it appears that neither he nor
his staff can meet this responsibility. First, he told us that neither
he nor his editorial staff would
take any responsibility for the debt
incurred last spring. Secondly, he
said that they would not take the
responsibility for failing to publish
the last two issues this year as they
are already in debt from the first
two issues. And lastly, if we could
not meet their financial demands
neither he nor his staff would take
the responsibility for publishing a
Vector next year.
Alternate solutions were offered to Mr. Polnitsky by Mr. Bilgrave and myself and it was made
clear that the Vector would receive a budget of $800 — $1,000
for next year.
Jed P. Luchow
Chairman, SAC

Sick at heart,

received no answer from the company. Great way to run an insurance company, write policies and
ignore claims. I wonder what size.
of a kickback the boys at Whitehead have received.
Bert Miller

The Johns Hopkins Viet Nam
Committee, which has declined recently due to a lack of interest on
the campus, is now making an attempt to revive itself to serve as a
vehicle of dissent for those who
oppose the war.
The Viet Nam Committee has
distributed almost 4,000 questionaires in order to determine the
mood of the students and faculty
members on campus. According to
a committee officer, response to
the survey indicates that opinion
at Hopkins runs more than threeto-one against the war.
27 Members
The group felt that the need
for reorganization, since, despite
the anti-war sentiment at Hopkins, membership in the committee
remains small. Since the October
Peace March, membership has declined until less than thirty people
remain actively participating. Many
students have left the Viet Nam
Committee in favor of the Students for McCarthy organization.
The organization has been restructured with three, or perhaps
four, subcommittees under a coordinating committee. First, there is
the committee for Hopkins Affairs,
designed to provide interest and
action on campus through a series
of debates and lectures by faculty
members.
Steady Stream
Second is the Press Committee,
Whose members would be informed on the policies of major news
Publications in regard to the war.
This committee is also responsible
for issuing a steady stream of letto the publications, condemn-

ing Viet Nam policies.
Third is the Literature Committee, responsible for the maintainance of the literature table in Levering Hall. Finally, a committee
to communicate with anti-war organizations on other campuses
might be formed. Its purpose
would be to orangize a united

front of thousands protesting the
war instead of the many small
groups which now exist.

Unsuccessful
The Committee has been less
than wholly successful in its revitalization program. Membership
and participation has not increased
appreciably. Those whom the corn-

mittee asks to conduct lectures or
debates feel that enough is already
being done.
The leadership of the committee would like to merge their organization with another group at
Hopkins. This move, they feel
would lend a broader base to the
anti-war movement on campus. At

this point, the members are urged
to join Students for McCarthy,
RESIST, or both. The Viet Nam
Committee believes that the only
way to achieve any of its goals is
through a large and unified organization, comprised of all of the
anti-war factions.

By KENNETH BOND
It is ironic that a little over
four months ago there were five
legitimate contenders for the Republican presidential nomination.
Now there is only one: Richard
M. Nixon, or two if you're counting Harold Stassen. When Big
George pulled out last week he was
only stating the obvious. He came
in like a winner and went out
gracefully. But in between Romney died from a severe case of
foot-in-mouth disease. His "great
White father" image smacked of
hypocrisy; his rising from the rear
strategy was politically perverse.
So now George Romney is a tool
of the historian's imagination.
Farewell, George.
To those of us, however, who
dread giving the GOP nod to Nixon
as a sop for saving the party banner all these many years, Romney
could have been a little more courageous to withdraw in favor of
another contender, i.e. Nelson
Rockefeller, his long-time supportter. Perhaps it was just bad timing,
Or maybe George and Rocky
haven't been so buddy-buddy after
all. But the long hoped for exit of
Romney in favor of Rockefeller
Went over like a lead balloon.
Rockefeller is no closer to being in
the race a week after Romney's
fall than he was a week before.
And that is the real loss for the
GOP.
As Governor Agnew pointed
out, Nixon's triumph over Strassen
in New Hampshire will prove absolutely nothing. Carrying the
point further, Governor
McCall
mcCall of Oregon stated at the
National Governors Conference in
Washington that unless Rockefeller
enters the race, and does so soon,
the series of six primaries leading
to the Miami Beach convention
Will amount to a grandiose farce.
If Popularly advocated contenders
uon't compete in the primaries,
then the purpose of the primary
election system to democratize
the electoral process will go up in
smoke this year. Thus, with Romney's withdrawal, there exists a'
Wide and possibly dangerous vacuum within the moderate to liberal leadership of the GOP.
It seems hard to believe that
any
but Rockefeller can fill
this void. Charles Percy still remains the idol of idealistic dreamers, the dark horse to pull out of
the stable in the event of a deadlock at the convention. Ronald
Reagan doesn't have a prayer for
the
nomination unless something
quite fatal happens to Nixon. That
°Id story about conservative
sT,trength abandoning Nixon for
rkeagan just never came true. Howas one travels among Young
ePublican circles, it is fair to ad11t that the California governor
LitpeS attract considerable admira1°n from the greasier reactionaries
of the Y.R.
element.
If Rockefeller doesn't get into
bthe fight,
the Republican party will
ke In serious trouble this Novemue.r. No doubt, Richard Nixon,
with his well calculated new image,
'ind. his well oiled and far reaching
Political machine will walk away
with the prize as things currently
stand. Then we can all enjoy
a.nother four years of good, old
Lyndon (if we live that long), beePtse no matter what tricky Dick
uoes to hypnotize the Republican
eon. vention delegates,
he just isn't
ing to pull the wool over 65 milsiOn American voters' eyes. Put
,R)r.tlY. Nixon hasn't sold a used
`ar m an awfully long time.
Al t has to be Rockefeller now.
point to it, regardless of
°fliney's wishy-washy withdraw-

al, Nixon's machine, or Rocky's
own reluctancy to act. Yet for
many who looked at the GOP as
the rostrum of hope and new vitality in the American political system year or so ago, it is depressing
to admit that the best the party
has to offer is a super-Machiavelli
and a governor who just wants to
fade away peacefully. Where is the
vigor and excitement that John F.
Kennedy brought to the political
arena? What happened to the imaginative programs that would end
poverty and war? Is the Golden
Age of America behind us? At this
eleventh hour in our history, Nelson A. Rockefeller is the last remaining hope that could realistically assure us of a better world
tomorrow.

Anti - Climactical Venom Titillates Town
By JAMES BENNETT
You saw the ad. Venom! Debauchery on the beach and in the
bedroom! Banned in Denmark!
No admittance under 18! With the
inevitable result that we all hotfooted it down to the 7th East,
flashed our student cards, scrambled into our seats, and foreheads
beaded with perspiration sat waiting for the curtain to rise with delicious visions of Scandanavian
perversions dancing through our
heads.
All of which made for an exasperating evening. For every time
the plot was threatening to thicken
(congeal is perhaps closer) the action would be blocked out by an
enormous X which, in order to fill
in the gaps in the story line, automatically forced one to employ his
imagination (Which is sorely deficient to begin with. Why else
would I have paid the fare?).
If one can conceive of the intellectual fodder resulting from
Francoise Sagan rewriting Bonjour
Tristesse while in her late forties
then one has a somewhat clearer

picture of what Venom had to offer the viewer. For it's all about
this positively beastly young man
named Per who sets about corrupting the morals of sweet little Suzanne, the innocent (but built)
daughter of a wealthy businessman
who is himself experiencing marital woes.
Scintillating in her
one piece bathing suit our heroine
is seductively stretched out on the
family's private water front soaking up the sun and trying to cram
for University finals when she
meets Evil Incarnate in the guise
of Per. Now Per, if you're still
with me, seeing what he likes best
ignores the posted Do Not Enter
signs, storms up the beach, snows
poor Suzanne before she can so
much as turn another page in her
Biology text, and proceeds, all in
one shot, to convince her to star
in a film he is currently piecing together on the hypocrisy of traditional morals. With a little help
from his friends Per eventually
manages to come up with some
downright fascinating home movies. With absolutely nothing going

to the cutting room floor Suzanne's mother is given a sneak preview and nearly gags at her daughter's indelicate part. Needless to
say daddy is telephoned at the office straight away.
Well after that the tension just
hits a feverish'pitch. And there we
sat, horny little prigs that we are,
while director Knud Leif Thornsen (pronounced nude leaf) rambled on about the nasty and less
than discrete morals practised by
mom and dad and Suzanne and
Per. And we lapped it up.
Sad to think that Pietro Germi's
tender tale of real life and real
morals should be prematurely ushered out by the management to
make room for something as dismal as this. For those faster than a
speeding bullet who , like myself,
managed to catch The Climax before its almost simultaneous arrival
and departure were treated to a
poignantly filmed story of a wildly
energetic Italian who happens to
have three wives stashed around
the countryside., The strain of an
impossible family life has begun to

cleanse his conscience by confessing all to a priest. But his domestic problems prove just as complicated to his kindly confessor who
is unable to suggest a workable
solution. "What can I do?" the
penitent Don Juan asks helplessly.
"Should I divorce them?" The
good father at this point is at his
wits end as to how he should best
counsel this sorrowful sinner.
Bleary-eyed after much soul
searching he blurts out hopelessly,
"Yes, yes, divorce. That's it." But
it was only an unguarded emotional outburst and he quickly recants.
"My, God," he cries. "Divorce!
What am I saying!"
The dialogue of Climax reveals
the real world, and the sheltered
world of the Church whose decrees periodically emanate from
behind the cloistered stone walls
of the Vatican. Director Germi
raises the question as to whether
the Catholic Hierarchy can, even in
its infinite wisdom, truly establish
feasible guidelines for moral conduct in an impossible world.

BILL SWARTZ — Senior co-captain battles Hal White of Towson
State. Swartz went on to defeat White 8-2, in the semi-final round of
the Mason Dixon tournament.
SWIMMING CHAMPIONSHIPS
Last weekend with only six swimmers and one diver the Jays' varsity squad ended its season and finished fifth in the Middle Atlantic
Conference swimming and diving championships.
The Jays garnered two gold medals; both belonging to Howard
Chernick, who swept the butterfly events. Rick Wilson, the defending one meter broad champ, lost his first conference meet competition, finishing second behind Allen of Elizabethtown. Junior Vaughn
Weikel picked up two silver medals in the backstroke and 200 yd
individual medley.

Bill Charyk, the only Hopkins
student to hold a first degree black
belt in karate, yesterday leant
across his opponents, splintered
simultaneously five boards, and
shattered several cinder blocks in
a public demonstration at the
Newton H. White Athletic Center.
The purpose of the exhibition
was to give to students an idea of
what karate training can do. He also hopes to attract students to his
evening classes which are to begin
next Tuesday.
In addition to Charyk's tour de
force, several of his already ranked
students assisted in the hour program including basic holds and defences, spinning kicks, plus several
bouts of "free sparing",(a technically precise free-for-all).
Bill Charyk likewise demonstrated possible defences against knife
attacks. He also fought off six
"attackers" during the evening.
Charyk teaches Tae Kwan Do,
the style of karate which is taught
to American Troops in Vietnam.

It is also the most preferred style
of the V.C. Tae K wan Do, one of
twenty karate styles, was introduced through Korea.
There are five stages of expertise leading finally to the black belt
status. The initial or beginning
stage is the gold belt, followed by
the green, the blue, the brown and
the black belt.
At present, Charyk has five officially ranked students: four
freshmen holding the gold belt
and one blue belt. Charyk stated
that, in order to pass the first degree, student must work for somewhere between five to seven
months. Charyk has studied karate
for five years.
Jhoan Rhee, considered to be
the best instructor of karate in the
United States, has taught Charyk
during the last several years. Out
of nine possible degrees, Rhee is a
seventh degree black belt
The course which Charyk is
giving will hold its first meeting on
Tuesday, March 12, at 7:30.

Hopkins Grapplers
Take Poor Fifth

JAY'S NEST

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Smashed 92-53 by eventual
winner Muhlenberg in the M.A.C.
tournament's opening round, the
varsity basketball team concluded
another so-so campaign — Hopkins'
twenty-second consecutive nonwinning cage season — with a 9-10
overall mark.
In last Friday's tourney action,
Muhlenberg, host of the Southern
Division Middle Atlantic Conference affair, jumped off to an 18-8
edge over the first-seeded Jays by
9:41 of the first half; and held
leads of from eight to fourteen
points until midway through the
second. Ahead 57-44 with 9:00
left, the Mules then turned on the
heat over the game's remainder,
scoring sixteen straight points in
the ensuing three minutes while
blitzing the bewildered Homewood
squad 35-9 down the stretch.
Although the affair hardly rated
as one of Hopkins' better hoop
performances (the team shot 30%
from the field,and made but seven
of sixteen free throws), the size of
the loss was more a function of
Muhlenberg capabilities than Jay
inadequacies.The Allentown,(Pa.)
squad, whose fourth-place M.A.C.
finish belied its tournament showing and resulted mainly from its
own inconsistency, was probably
